Hi Sebastien.

Not sure if you mean my message when you mention the confus=
ing sentence construction, or the original link. In any case, you are corre=
ct: my use of the word "representing" may cause some confusion with the "re=
presentation" term used in REST. Apart from that, I don't understand why th=
e rest of your clarification, which seems quite correct but in a point, but=
 unrelated. Let me clarify:

1. The UUDI mentioned in the fedora project li=
nk is, as I understand, an internal ID representing some data entity. The c=
onfusion comes when we call that an "Identifier" and mention, in the same s=
entence, that we can access the resource having that ID and the entry point=
 URI. That ID is supposed to be created by the server in order to permanent=
ly identify the "resource", since the URIs may change over time, the Fedora=
 site says. This is like having two resource identifiers, one that is the U=
RI and another one internal.

2. My explanation: that is not quite right. T=
hat internal identifier is part of the entity implementation and should not=
 be used to identify the resource by itself, but it can be used to identify=
 the entity. The resource identifier is the URI. Those internal identifiers=
 are nice at the business level, and the correct way of using them is throu=
gh a search or other mechanism that can map that internal ID to one resourc=
e, using REST constrains. Simple. 

3. So, to me, it is a bad practice to m=
ake the server create an ID outside the business layer, expose it and someh=
ow associate that to the resource identification, say by using URI template=
s. This leads to business exposure in the identification, plus reduces the =
server control on the URI space, plus some other inconveniences.

4. About =
the resource and representation, yes, people usually think of a resource to=
 be its representation, or that a resource is simply a data record. They ar=
e three completely different things, although a resource may require the re=
presentation and the data record to be implemented.

5. Now, entity to me i=
s not an implementation. We have the logical model where we define an entit=
y, with properties and behavior and such, and then in the "physical" model =
we implement that, either with a data record, an EDI file or an XML file, a=
 service or an object. That is, I disagree a little with your definition of=
 entity=3D body+medatada=3D representation. A representation is simply a bu=
nch of bytes, a copy of state, a description message, not an implementation=
 of the entity. We can have some entity information, we put it in a format =
(say plain XML) and send it to the server, which in turn creates a resource=
 (that would be an entity implementation) and that resource starts its life=
 somewhere in that cloud. We may get all or partial information from that e=
ntity implementation (the resource) by requesting a representation of the r=
esource using the URI to identify it. So, entity (pure information) <> reso=
urce(Implementation of an Entity) <> representation (binary "view" of a res=
ource).

Hope this allows a clearer reading of what I meant.

Cheers!

Will=
iam Martinez.


--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Sebastien Lambla <seb@=
...> wrote:
>
> Seems there is a lot of confusing sentence construction in =
that message, or it doesn't carry the right terminology, can't quite say.
>=
 
> Resource Identifier: A URI.
> Resource: A concept / temporal mapping th=
at has a Resource Identifier
> Representation: A binary stream that contain=
s the state of a Resource at the time of retrieval.
> 
> If you move a repr=
esentation between two URIs, you have changed neither the resource (the two=
 things identified by the URIs) nor the identifiers. You've changed the sta=
te of the resource, and that's it.
> 
> Just because you move the represent=
ation from /posts/latest to /post/nearlylatest and assign a new represetnat=
ion to /posts/latest, you have not changed what the resource is or how it i=
s identified, you just changed the state (the entity in this case, where en=
tity =3D body + metadata, which is what we call the representation).
> 
> S=
eb
